statement.tex: \text{Prove that the function given by }\\ \quad\quad f(x)=x^2-x+1 \\ \text{is neither strictly increasing nor strictly }\\ \text{decreasing on }\left(-1,1\right).

step.context: \text{In the graph below, is the function strictly}\\ \text{increasing between points A and C?}
step.reason: f(x)\text{ is increasing between A and C - but not strictly.}\\ \quad\quad\dfrac{d}{dx}f(x) = 0\text{ between A and B.}\\ \text{In a strictly increasing function, }\dfrac{d}{dx}f(x)\gt 0.
\text{The key word here is 'strictly'. For a function to be }\\ \text{strictly increasing/decreasing, }\\ f'(x)\gt 0\text{ or }f'(x)\lt 0\text{ but not } = 0.
